variant.title: The FINITE STRING Newsletter
variant.bodyText: The 19th Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics will be held at Stanford University, in Stanford, California, Monday, June 29, through Wednesday, July 1, 1981. Twenty-five con- tributed papers will be presented in five sessions, and there will be two panel discussions. Additionally, there will be the Annual Business Meeting and the Conference Banquet. The program committee for the meeting was chaired by C. Raymond Perrault, Univer- sity of Toronto, and consisted of Bertram Bruce, Bolt Beranek and Newman, Jaime Carbonell, Carnegie- Mellon University, Mitchell Marcus, Bell Labs, Ellen Prince, University of Pennsylvania, and Ralph Weische- del, University of Delaware. Local arrangements are being handled by Jerry Kaplan, Stanford University. Copies of the proceedings will be available at the time of the conference.
variant.note: SUNDAY, JUNE 28, 1981 6:00-10:00 P.M. Registration and Reception Terman Engineering Center Lobby MONDAY, JUNE 29, 1981 8:00 A.M.

variant.bodyText: Registration. Before June 1, 1981, the registration fee is $25 for members, $40 for non-members, and $10 for full-time students. After June 1, the fee is $5 higher in each category. The non-member registration fee includes individual membership in the ACL for 1981 (regular dues: $15). Registration includes a copy of the conference proceedings. Advance reserva- tions are required for the conference banquet on Tues- day evening, at $15 per person. Dormitory accommodations. A limited number of single and double rooms with shared bath facilities and maid service are available on campus in Roble Hall with advance reservations for the three day period June 28-30. Reservations should be made by June 10 to ensure accommodations, although it may still be possi- ble to obtain them after that time. The cost for the three-day period is $42.75 for a single and $32.25 (per person) for a double. Accom- modations will be available for additional days, subject to availability, at a daily rate of $14.25 for a single and $10.75 (per person) for a double. When request- ing additional days, the particular dates required must be specified. If no roommate is specified for double rooms, please indicate whether you are male or female and smoker or nonsmoker. Motel accommodations. A list of motels in the area is available on request. Directions to Stanford University. The university is about 25 minutes drive from both the San Francisco International and the San Jose Municipal Airports. Take the Bayshore Freeway (Route 101) to the Uni- versity Avenue exit in Palo Alto. University Avenue will take you through downtown Palo Alto, and be- come Palm Drive after crossing over an underpass at the entrance to the Stanford Campus. At the first stop sign (not a stop light) after the underpass, turn right onto Campus Drive. Where Campus Drive ends, turn left onto Panama Street. Where Panama Street ends, turn right onto Sam Morris Way, then left onto Santa Teresa Street. Make an immediate right into Roble Drive. Roble Hall will be in front of you; Ter- man Engineering Center will be behind you. Limousine service ($16.75) is available from both airports, and Van service ($8.00) is available from San Francisco; advance reservations are advisable through Airport Limousine Service, (415) 595-3636. If taking the Van, get off at the Tressider Memorial Union stop, a short walk from Roble Hall. The SAMTRANS Ex- press Airport Bus, #7F, ($0.55) leaves every half hour from the airport; hourly after 6:25 P.M.
variant.page: 48 American Journal of Computational Linguistics, Volume 7, Number 1, January-March 1981
